title: Plummeting bank stocks lead global selloff as fear of private credit ‘contagion’ moves across equities and the dollar - Fortune
summary:
It has not been that high since President Trump roiled the market with his Liberation Day tariffs in April.
Until yesterday afternoon, few people outside Utah and Arizona had ever heard of Zions Bancorporation or Western Alliance Bank.
What happened next was extraordinary: 74 American bank stocks lost $100 billion in market cap as the S&P 500 declined 0.63%.
Investors are spooked by the First Brands scandal, in which the car parts supplier took more than $10 billion in loans on the private credit market and then went bankrupt.
Expect great scrutiny over upcoming regional bank earnings, with any further spillover into U.S. stocks set to extend the dollar selloff,” Pesole said.

title: Private credit: what critics miss and what founders need to know - Fortune
summary:
What private credit actually is Private debt is, at its core, lending by non-bank institutions directly to private companies.
What’s changed is the role private debt now plays in the capital stack.
Yes, private credit sits outside traditional bank regulation, but that doesn’t mean it operates in the shadows.
Many private debt vehicles are publicly listed or institutionally backed.
In this environment, private debt offers a bridge to sustainability, to scale, to stronger future valuations.

title: Was The Panic Over Bad Loans That Sent Bank Stocks Reeling Overdone? - Investopedia
summary:
Regional bank stocks rose on Friday, rebounding from a sell-off yesterday as investors assessed the fallout from recent bankruptcies and fraud allegations that have raised concerns about lending standards.
Zions shares rose nearly 6% today, bouncing back from yesterday's 13% slide, while Western Alliance shares added 3%.
Concerns about lending practices first surfaced early last month when subprime lender Tricolor declared bankruptcy amid allegations of fraud.
This year, the Fed included in its annual bank stress test an assessment of the risks posed by NDFI lending.
The central bank estimated that loan losses at the largest banks would total $490 billion over two years if credit quality deteriorated across their NDFI portfolios.

title: Bank fears spread with wider market spooked over credit 'cockroaches' (ZION:NASDAQ) - Seeking Alpha
summary:
Bank fears spread with wider market spooked over credit 'cockroaches' Comments (88) As Warren Buffett once famously said, "There is seldom just one cockroach in the kitchen."
That saying is now being echoed by the top brass of the financial world, with big banks to regional players taking substantial loan loss charges this week amid Quick Insights Recent bankruptcies such as Tricolor Holdings have led major banks like JPMorgan and others to take substantial loan loss charges and highlight exposure to unsustainable debts and potentially fraudulent activities.
Despite market nerves and sharp sell-offs, these loan losses are currently viewed as isolated and not fully representative of a systemic banking crisis, though vigilance is warranted.
Banking troubles have caused Treasury yields to fall sharply, the Fed's repo facility to be used, broad equity sell-offs across regions, and signals of illiquidity in money markets.

title: Wall Street credit worries intensify after Dimon's 'cockroach' warning - Yahoo Finance
summary:
Wall Street's credit worries are intensifying after a warning from JPMorgan Chase (JPM) CEO Jamie Dimon about cockroaches in the US economy.
The regional banks that plummeted on Thursday were Phoenix-based Western Alliance Bancorporation (WAL) and Salt Lake City's Zions Bancorporation (ZION).
The disclosures are the latest in a series of developments that have worried Wall Street as investors look for signs that credit among commercial customers is weakening.
The aftermath revealed a web of exposures among large Wall Street players, including Jefferies Financial Group (JEF).
The firm's investment exposure is effectively "$43 million in accounts receivable" and "$2 million of interest on First Brands' bank loans," the executives said.

title: Analyzing a Bank’s Financial Statements: An Example - Investopedia
summary:
Banks' financial statements are unique, especially when analyzing revenue.
When the interest a bank earns from loans exceeds the interest paid on deposits, it generates income from the interest rate spread.
Loans are assets because the bank earns interest income from loans.
Important Although a liability on a bank's balance sheet, deposits are critical to the bank's lending ability.
If interest rates rise, banks tend to earn more interest income, but when rates fall, banks are at risk as interest income declines.
